intro: Calendula repanda, commonly known as the common calendula, is a flowering plant in the sunflower family, Asteraceae. It is native to southern Europe and western Asia and is characterized by its bright yellow to orange petals and prominent central disk. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces daisy-like flowers that bloom from late spring to early autumn. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are upright and often slightly hairy. Calendula repanda is widely cultivated for its ornamental value and has been used in traditional medicine for its anti-inflammatory and antiseptic properties.
